unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26 - India continues its push towards a sustainable future with significant developments in renewable energy. Dr. Meera Sharma, a leading environmental scientist at IIT Madras, highlights the importance of solar power for rural electrification.

Recent initiatives include the installation of solar panels in several villages in Rajasthan, bringing electricity to households previously reliant on kerosene lamps. The National Institute of Solar Energy (NISE) is offering training programs to local communities on the maintenance of these systems, fostering self-sufficiency.

The government has also announced new subsidies for rooftop solar installations, making it more affordable for homeowners. A typical rooftop system covering 500 sq ft can now generate enough electricity to significantly reduce electricity bills, potentially saving homeowners Rs. 15,000 annually. Furthermore, wind energy projects are gaining momentum in coastal states like Gujarat, harnessing the power of the Arabian Sea. These projects aim to reduce carbon emissions and promote a cleaner environment, aligning with India's commitment to the Paris Agreement.
